facts.text: The respondent made advance payment of tax under section 18A of the Income-tax Act for the assessment year 1952-53.
On August 30, 1952, regular assessment for 1952-53 was made and a part of the tax paid in advance was found refundable to the respondent.

Under sub-section 5 of section 18A, as it then stood, interest at a certain rate was payable on the amount paid in advance; Rs. 14,720-14-0 was found payable and paid to the respondent some time in September, 1952.
On May 24, 1953, sub-section 5 of section 18A was amended with effect from April 1, 1952, under which the Government was to have paid Rs. 9,404-5-0 instead of Rs. 14,720-14-0.

On March 18, 1957, a notice was issued under section 34(1)(b) stating that the Income-tax Officer had reason to believe that the respondent's income for the assessment year ending March 31, 1953, had been under-assessed and had been the subject of excessive relief, proposing to reassess.
The respondent protested the notice under section 34(1)(b).

Notwithstanding the protest, assessment under section 34 was made on July 30, 1957; the order stated that as per amended section 18A(5), assessee entitled to smaller interest, excessive relief allowed under section 23(3), action under section 34 to recover excess interest.
On application under article 226, the High Court of Bombay set aside the order of reassessment dated July 30, 1957.
This appeal arises out of the High Court order setting aside the reassessment.

legal_issues.text: Whether the reassessment under section 34(1)(b) of the Income-tax Act, 1922, was valid to recover excess interest paid under section 18A(5) due to retrospective amendment, on grounds of under-assessment or excessive relief.

petitioner_arguments.text: Reassessment valid under section 34(1)(b) as income under-assessed or subject of excessive relief; notice stated these grounds.
The form of notice of demand shows interest under section 18A taken into account in computing tax, so excess interest is excessive relief.
Sub-sections 8 and 11 of section 18A show interest is part of tax, so excess interest allowed is excessive relief.
Order of July 30, 1957, supportable under section 35.

respondent_arguments.text: The form of notice of demand does not treat interest as part of tax; it is deducted to arrive at demand.
Sections 18A(8) and 18A(11) deal with interest payable by assessee, not by Government.

court_reasoning.text: None of the conditions under section 34(1)(b) fulfilled: no escape of assessment, under-assessment, low rate, excessive relief, or excessive loss/depreciation.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Notice relied on under-assessment or excessive relief, but order based only on excessive relief; income not under-assessed.

court_reasoning.text: Case is of over-assessment provisionally on advance tax, not under-assessment; interest payment not relief in computing income but statutory liability per law then in force.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Retrospective amendment reduces State's liability but computation at time was correct; cannot reopen under section 34.

court_reasoning.text: Form of demand treats interest as deduction from net tax, not part of tax.
Sections 18A(8) and 18A(11) concern interest by assessee, not Government to assessee.
Reference to M. Chockalingam v. Commissioner does not apply as it concerns penal interest payable by assessee, not interest by Government.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Not concerned with penal interest here.

court_reasoning.text: Leave refused to argue section 35 as not raised below and action expressly under section 34.

holdings.text: Reassessment under section 34 not applicable as no under-assessment or excessive relief; interest computation was per law in force at time.

precedents_cited.case_name: M. Chockalingam v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents_cited.relevance: Concerned penal interest payable by assessee, not interest payable by Government to assessee

statutes_cited.name: Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs advance tax, interest on advance, reassessment for escaped income/excessive relief; amendment to s.18A(5) retrospective

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for High Court writ quashing reassessment order

outcome.summary: Appeal held entirely without substance; High Court order setting aside reassessment under section 34 upheld as reassessment not justified under the section.
outcome.relief_granted: Reassessment order quashed (upheld from High Court)

key_quotes.text: This appeal is entirely without substance.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: It does not seem to us that it is a case where the respondents income was under-assessed or where excessive relief was granted in computing that income.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: That computation cannot be reopened under section 34 because it cannot be said that it is a case either of under-assessment or of excessive relief having been granted.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains why retrospective amendment does not trigger reassessment
